poem:
**Rebuilding Brinsley Headstocks**

They lift the steel bones back,
hefting past shadows
of men leathered in coal dust,
their distant lamps flicker in twilight—
those histories cracked open and filled,
once more, we listen 
to the creak of old iron,
arms reaching down, lifting up:
an echo from earth's silent mouth
reborn into sky.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Brinsley Headstocks mining landmark to be reconstructed after public outcry Councillors in Broxtowe, in Nottinghamshire, have unanimously voted to replace Brinsley Headstocks in their original form, after the dismantling of the structure last year due to safety concerns prompted a backlash from residents. The headstocks, the last remaining structure of the type in England, were used to transport men and coal up and down mines in the area from 1872 until the last colliery closed". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
